results.title: People you'd like to know: Dee: Larsen's Syndrome
results.creator_credit: Janet Weaver and WGBH Educational Foundation
results.brief_description: Dee has Larsen’s Syndrome - a disease which affects bone formation and joint location. She needs leg braces and canes to walk, but her outlook is optimistic and positive. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Orientation of the camera
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Lessons in visual language”.
Looks at the relationship of the viewer to the screen, and the way in which attention is absorbed into the world of the filmmaker, affecting the viewer’s own orientation. Notes also the physical support of the camera and its orientation in space.

group_siblings.title: Lenses and perspective: how does it look from where you are?
Shot sizes and framing faults: Episode 2

results.title: Movement and moving the camera
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Lessons in visual language”.
Illustrates movement within the frame, movement of the frame and movement of the camera. Notes the creation of the sense of movement without moving the frame, and how and when the camera can be used subjectively. Narrated by Peter Thompson.

group_siblings.title: Lenses and perspective: how does it look from where you are?
Shot sizes and framing faults: Episode 2

results.title: Lenses and perspective: how does it look from where you are?
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Lessons in visual language”.
Lays to rest the mistaken idea that focal length affects the appearance of depth. Demonstrates that the camera-to-subject distance is the governing factor in the perception of spatial relationships in the third dimension. Devised and narrated by Peter Thompson.

results.title: Dinosaurs: the age of the terrible lizard
results.brief_description: An animated film which presents an overview of the dinosaur age, showing the major types of dinasaurs and some of their behavioural characteristics. Gives evidence of evolutionary development and indicates a possible reason for their becoming extinct. Edited version of film “Dinozaury”.

results.title: Cheechako's first day
results.creator_credit: Derek W. Muirden and Film Loft Productions
results.brief_description: Shows the debut of a polar bear cub in an Oregon zoo, his reactions to new surroundings, the subtle ways in which the mother bear cares for and trains her cub, and the ways in which these animals adapt to the urban environment. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: Milk: from farm to you. - 3rd ed.
results.creator_credit: James Kennedy, Thomas Smith and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Follows the complete cycle of milk production, including the necessity of conception and calving. Explains homogenisation and pasteurisation, and depicts the production of related dairy products such as cheese and icecream. Suitable for secondary level.

results.title: Fire
results.brief_description: Animated impressionistic film portraying an idyllic forest alive with plants and animals that suddenly grows quiet as ominous clouds of black smoke roll over the landscape, and fire consumes everything in its path.

results.title: Women at work: change, choice, challenge
results.creator_credit: William Kay and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Presents on-the-job profiles of women in a variety of careers, including traditionally male-dominated ones. Explores the attitudes that direct women toward particular career choices, and indicates some of the problems both men and women encounter in competing for jobs and as co-workers.

results.title: Islands in the stream
results.creator_credit: Franklin J. Schaffner, Max Palewsky, Peter Bart and Paramount Communications
results.brief_description: Abridged version of Hemingway’s novel. An artist living alone on his island retreat is visited by his sons. Over the summer, he discovers their mutual need and respect. (This section, however, is not representative of the theme of the novel as a whole). Suitable for upper secondary level.
